text_description: Allows religious exemptions from immunization requirements for students attending religiously affiliated private schools, with documentation provided by a caregiver
Prohibits governmental entities and county health departments from using public funds to produce or distribute materials that promote vaccination
Specifies that religious exemptions to immunization requirements are permitted with a written declaration from a parent or guardian
Allows parents or guardians to exempt their minor children from school immunization requirements by submitting a signed statement citing religious, medical, or philosophical objections
Outlines a Parental Bill of Rights, including a provision that emphasizes parents' right to exempt their children from immunizations
Would require that communications regarding school vaccine mandates include information on the process for obtaining exemptions
Codifies the requirement that insurers fully cover all vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)
Proposed expanding the state's immunization reporting system, currently focused on child immunization data, to routinely collect information on adult immunizations

Requires the state Medicaid program to reimburse providers for administering RSV immunizations at the same rate as the Vaccines for Children (VFC) program, and prohibits civil liability against providers who administer these immunizations
Allow pharmaceutical company officers to be held criminally liable for "vaccine harm"
Repeals the requirement that children must be immunized in order to receive CalWORKs benefits
Establishes a state stockpile of vaccines
Establishes the inclusion of sexual orientation and gender identity data within the State Immunization Information System (IIS)
Would authorize state to modify or supplement baseline vaccine recommendations, taking into account guidance from leading medical organizations

Specifies that if the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) is repealed, modified, or otherwise ceases to operate, the commissioner of insurance retains the authority to require vaccine coverage by insurers

Directs the State Board of Health to consider vaccination recommendations from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and other professional organizations, in addition to those from the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), when establishing immunization requirements; Includes additional changes to school immunization provisions
Would expand exemptions to state-mandated vaccination laws for school-aged children to allow philosophical exemptions based on personal, moral, or other beliefs

Would allow students to recover actual and punitive damages for injuries or illnesses caused by a vaccination program if the state required the student to receive the vaccine as a condition of school admission
Would authorize pharmacists to administer vaccines to children, regardless of age
Would reestablish religious exemptions for school vaccination requirements
Would establish an annual public education campaign to inform residents about free and low-cost vaccines

Pharmacists, pharmacy interns, and nationally certified pharmacy technicians who have completed an accredited training program, are currently trained in CPR, and have notified the Delaware Board of Pharmacy may administer immunizations via a prescriber's order or protocol for patients aged 3 years and older.

Provides for the reimbursement of vaccine administration fees to eligible providers for vaccines administered to eligible children under the Vaccines for Children (VFC) program, in accordance with rates set by the Division of Medicaid and Medical Assistance in conjunction with the CDC. If funding levels permit, these funds may also be used to upgrade and maintain the state immunization registry (DelVAX).
Would establish a Primary and Preventive Care Grant Program to provide funding to providers in rural areas of the state, which may be used to purchase vaccines
Would establish a universal state health plan ('Florida Health Plan') that includes coverage for vaccines
Prohibits discrimination based on vaccination status in educational institutions
Would require acceptance of religious and personal medical exemptions to mandated immunizations
Would direct the health department to pursue a Medicaid waiver to provide full immunization coverage for individuals experiencing homelessness
Would require schools to report deidentified vaccination and exemption data to the state
Would codify the requirement for insurers to fully cover all vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)
Would require the state to compile individual death and vaccination records and publish aggregated data on a quarterly basis
Would establish an opt-out procedure for required vaccines based on health, religious, or philosophical grounds
Would allow individuals to claim exemption from vaccine requirements if the vaccine does not meet several strict criteria
Would prohibit the addition of any new childhood vaccine requirements beyond those currently mandated
Would allow for "conscience exemptions" from vaccination requirements
Would require a parent or legal guardian to be present for vaccine administration to a minor
Would prohibit the use of an exemption to immunization due to conscientiously held beliefs for immunization against measles, mumps, and rubella
Would establish a state health plan covering child immunizations
Would require a parent or legal guardian to be present for vaccination of a minor
Would establish a "Bill of Rights" for vaccine recipients, requiring "independent information from sources other than vaccine manufacturers, governmental entities, or quasi-governmental entities"
Would expand and facilitate non-medical vaccination exemptions
Would prohibit provider incentives for vaccination
Would expand non-medical exemptions to include philosophical and conscientious exemptions
Would allow dentists to administer vaccines to their patients

This constitutional amendment would prohibit laws or policies from infringing upon individuals' right to refuse medical procedures, potentially overriding existing laws limiting exemptions to medical or religious reasons.
Would allow pharmacy technicians to administer vaccines
Would establish a "parental bill of rights," including reinforcing parents' ability to opt out of school immunization (e.g., via religious exemptions)
Would require that local and county health departments receive state-level approval for vaccination efforts
Would require health insurance plans to cover recommended childhood vaccines
Would remove school requirement for varicella (chicken pox), Hepatitis B, and Hib vaccines; would remove authority of Commissioner of Health and Human Services to make vaccine rules
Would eliminate the form needed to obtain a religious exemption, allowing such exemptions with a signed statement from a parent
Would prohibit requiring childhood immunization with vaccines that have not been shown to prevent transmission of disease in clinical trials
Would repeal the state's Vaccine Association, which is responsible for the universal purchase of vaccines
comments: Retained - will come back next session for a vote

text_description: Would authorize access for insurers to the state's immunization registry
Would add additional requirements to obtain consent for vaccination, such as vaccine insert and VAERS reporting to guardian 48 hours prior to vaccine administration
comments: Was introduced in 2024 but is still part of current session and can still be voted on

text_description: Would require parents to opt in to NJ Immunization Information System
Would create a "Children's Vaccination Bill of Rights," emphasizing vaccine opt-out
Would require rotavirus immunization for school attendance
Would remove reference to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) in the state's meningococcal vaccine recommendation
Would exempt private and parochial schools from immunization requirements
Would allow for religious vaccination exemptions
Would require providers to provide additional information about vaccines 48 hours ahead of administering
Would require vaccines added to state immunization schedule to have been approved by FDA for at least 3 years
Would prohibit health care providers from refusing patients who are not up-to-date on vaccinations
Would expand non-medical vaccination exemptions to include "conscientious objections"
Would establish a universal health care plan for state residents, including coverage for immunizations
Allows pharmacists and pharmacy technicians to administer vaccines to children 5 and over
Would require providers to give caregivers additional information and obtain written consent before administering vaccines
Would prohibit discrimination based on vaccination status, including for schoolchildren
Proposes an amendment to the Oregon Constitution to prohibit requiring any specific vaccine unless encoded by state law
Would give money to Oregon Health Authority for the Vaccine Access Program, for vaccine purchases
Would require providers to continue caring for children who do not follow the recommended vaccine schedule, as long as they receive one vaccine each year
Would require schools to prominently disseminate information on how to obtain vaccination exemptions
Would allow the PA Department of Health to make the vaccine schedule, referring to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), AAP, and other sources
Would require insurers to fully cover preventive services, including immunization, without cost-sharing requirements
Would prohibit state or local governments from requiring vaccinations as a condition for accessing public services, including education
Includes RSV vaccination and monoclonal antibodies within the Vaccines for Children program
Requires the Department of Health to undertake preliminary education, outreach, and vaccination drive efforts at schools with vaccination rates under 30%
Establishes a universal funding program for immunizations, which will allow for the administration of vaccines at no cost
Would remove the option of non-medical exemptions to immunization requirements
Would establish a "Parental Bill of Rights" to include expanding non-medical exemptions for vaccine mandates
Allows pharmacists and pharmacy technicians to administer vaccines to children 3 years and older
Codifies immunization and documentation requirements for schools and daycares, including a simple opt-out process for exemptions
Would change inclusion in the state's immunization registry from opt-out to opt-in
Would require that all school communications to parents about vaccine requirements include information about non-medical exemptions and state that "immunizations are not mandatory"
Prohibits the mandate of any medical interventions, including vaccines, in the state (excluding facilities who receive Medicaid/Medicare and [pending legal interpretation] schools).
Urges government stakeholders to work with clinicians and families to ensure children are fully vaccinated before starting school
Declares a specified date as Vaccine Awareness Day to educate the public about the importance of vaccines and urges the Department of Health to continue prioritizing and investing in immunization
Would require health providers to administer a vaccine to a patient who is requesting it, as long as the provider has deemed it medically necessary and there is at least one dose available
Would prohibit vaccine mandates across settings
Would expand non-medical exemptions
Would establish state-level vaccination adverse event reporting system
Requires any public communications about vaccines requirements to include information about vaccine exemptions
Would require parents to opt-in to statewide immunization registry
Would remove requirement that children receiving independent private instruction provide proof of immunization to the state
Would eliminate vaccination requirements for child care centers and elementary/secondary schools
Would require child care facilities and educational institutions to grant exemptions from vaccine requirements without inquiring into the sincerity of the request
comments: Failed to pass in the 2023-2024 legislative session.

text_description: Would provide right to refuse vaccines for reasons of conscience
Would allow pharmacists to order and administer FDA-approved vaccines for individuals 7 years and older
Changes religious vaccine exemptions for childcare facilities to loosen exemption procedures for parents with “sincerely held” religious beliefs
Would prohibit health care providers from refusing to treat people who have not received a particular vaccine
Would expand non-medical vaccination exemptions to allow for conscientious objection
Would prohibit insurers from imposing cost-sharing requirements on preventive services, including routine immunizations
Would add steps to process to obtain informed consent before vaccine administration
Requires that communication issued about immunization requirements include information about exemptions
Increases the patient's fee for vaccines at public health units from $10 to $50
Urges Department of Health to improve access to immunization services in rural and low-income communities
Urges Department of Health to study relationship between sudden unexpected deaths of infants and children and the administration of vaccinations
Would restore religious exemptions to immunization requirements
Would establish Maine Health Plan for all residents, covering all childhood and adult vaccinations
Allows pharmacists to administer vaccines to children 3 years and older with a prescription
Repeals certain immunization requirements for a child to attend a public or private elementary or secondary school in the state
Would require county board of education to grant students temporary admission to schools if parent is unable to provide proof of immunization

Allows the health commissioner to adopt regulations as needed to ensure that health insurers cover all vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) as of December 2024.
Would establish Healthy Maryland Program, which would provide comprehensive, universal health care services for state residents, including immunizations
Would require all schools to annually report aggregate immunization data and to make school-level data public
Specifies requirements for obtaining exemptions to vaccine requirements and immunization data reporting
Would provide a $100 tax credit for residents who provide proof of vaccination
Would require insurers to cover recommended vaccines without cost-sharing
Would prohibit a requirement for Hepatitis B vaccinations for children under certain circumstances
comments: Died in committee in the 2023-2024 legislative session.

text_description: Would require insurers to cover recommended vaccines administered by pharmacists within insurer network
Permits pharmacists to order and administer vaccines to children 3 years and older
Urges CDC to include new RSV immunization technologies (including vaccines and monoclonal antibodies) within the federal Vaccines for Children Program
Would add requirements for obtaining a nonmedical exemption to vaccine requirements

bill_number: Puerto Rico Fundamental Right to Religious Freedom Act (Law No. 14 of April 13, 2025)
text_description: Prohibits government from voiding a religious vaccine exemption even during an epidemic unless parental consent is provided; adds requirements to informed consent process
Would include influenza in the list of diseases for which all children in preschool or school must be vaccinated, in accordance with recognized medical practices
Would change insurance coverage requirements to guarantee access to vaccination services
Requires schools to annually distribute immunization information, including information on how to obtain immunizations, in languages other than English
Would expand authority of pharmacists to administer vaccines
Preserves the ability of public officials to address communicable diseases
Requires preserving coverage of immunization services for children without cost sharing
Would prohibit vaccine mandates for private, parochial, charter, virtual charter, and remote public schools
Would allow for religious and philosophical exemptions to mandatory vaccination requirements and would revise the existing process to obtain a medical exemption
comments: Died in committee; combined multiple bills related to religious and philosophical exemptions

text_description: Would make immunization completely voluntary for students attending private schools
Would eliminate all vaccine mandates for school enrollment
Would establish a "Parents' Bill of Rights" that reaffirms the rights of parents to make vaccination decisions
Would expand vaccine exemptions, particularly in school settings, during an epidemic
Requires the Department of Health to make the school health entrance forms, including immunization forms, more user-friendly
Would allow for religious exemptions to immunization during epidemics
Proposes to publicize reporting by health providers of adverse events following immunization on the health department's website
Would allow optometrists to vaccinate during health emergencies
This education law, among various provisions, exempts students attending a home-based "microschool" or micro-education program from school immunization requirements.
comments: This bill was passed in to law on March 20, 2024

text_description: Would ensure appropriate compensation/reimbursement for vaccine administration
Would forbid the state from compelling any individual to undergo medical treatment, including vaccination, even during a declared emergency
Prohibits the enforcement or recognition of requirements or mandates issued by the World Health Organization as the basis for any official action
States that a child in state custody cannot be denied school admission due to lack of immunization or inability to provide immunization records
Remove vaccine requirements for students attending fully online private schools
Prohibits the state or local health department from promoting, distributing, or endorsing FDA-regulated products for uses not specified in their official labeling
Would remove the responsibility of parents or guardians to ensure that their child receives vaccines recommended by CDC/AAP guidelines
Specifies requirements of informed consent for vaccination
Would prohibit insurers from requiring prior authorization for vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)
comments: Died in committee; changing this to pro as by prohibiting prior authorization, removes adminsitrative and insurance related barriers

text_description: Would emphasize the rights of individuals to refuse medical treatments, including vaccines
Seeks to broadly prohibit vaccine mandates across settings
comments: Died in chamber; Make it illegal for anyoneâ€”including businesses, colleges, or the governmentâ€”to require vaccines, with penalties for doing so.Prohibit employers from punishing employees who refuse vaccination. Reduce state powers to enforce quarantines (removes National Guard support for quarantine, limits isolation to only symptomatic or exposed individuals, and sets a 21-day time limit for asymptomatic quarantine).Requires the state to monitor vaccine safety and efficacy.Removes the requirement that health care workers must help give vaccines to keep their license.Adds new definitions for â€œgene therapyâ€ and â€œvaccineâ€â€”potentially to restrict what can be mandated or promoted in the future.

text_description: Would establish a "Parental Bill of Rights," emphasizing parents' rights to make vaccine decisions for their children
Would require Medicaid reimbursement for immunization administration to be no less than 100% of the Medicare reimbursement rate
Would specify vaccine coverage and reimbursement rates
Would give pharmacists the authority to administer vaccines to individuals aged 3 years and older
Would establish a "Parental Bill of Rights," emphasizing parents’ authority to make vaccination decisions for their children
Would require healthcare professionals to obtain written informed consent, signed by a parent or guardian prior to administering a vaccine
comments: Pending in Senate Health and Human Services committee

text_description: Requires the health department to provide a blank affidavit form for claiming a vaccination exemption and to post it on their website
Proposes a constitutional amendment recognizing the right of an individual to refuse vaccination without impacting their ability to attend school
Establishes civil liability for vaccine manufacturers that advertise their products in the state if the vaccine causes harm or injury
comments: Not sure if we should be including this

text_description: Would prohibit discrimination by health care providers based on vaccination status
Would change state immunization registry from opt-in to opt-out and create clear procedures for those who want their information excluded
Would prohibit the state from infringing on the fundamental rights of parents, including making immunization-related decisions
Would prohibit the Department of Health Services from requiring additional vaccines for school attendance
Would establish a program to provide vaccines to individuals who are not eligible to receive the vaccines at no cost from a federal program
Would remove certain requirements to obtain non-medical exemptions to vaccine requirements
Allows pharmacy technicians to abstain from administering immunizations to children under 13 years
Would establish parental rights in a minor child's health care, repealing a provision authorizing vaccination of a minor without parental consent
